1793 WD 7mo: 222     my Coat & rang it, & put it on again, and being unwell with the fever & Unclear, it seemed impossible as thought to travel, and with great difficulty assended the hills, I was threatned with the lifted up Tomyhawk, & expected every minute for sometime to fall a sacrafice, but thro' the goodness of a bountiful preserver, my life was spared, we went about 25 miles, about to o'6lock at night, they stop'd, made a fire, & got some refreshment, & two went back I suppose several Miles to see if any body was following, and about 12 O'clock we started again, & run in a little trot, til just before day, & one on each side dragged me along, til they came into a low bottom, where they struck up a small fire and rested a few hours, & so we continued travelling with great expedition, living on parched Corn beat into flour mix'd with maple sugar & water, which is very refreshing; but as they were cautious of firing off a gun, we had but little opportunity of getting meat; but to prevent being discovered, when they encamp, they send some back upon the track, and when they leave the Camp, they separate with their particular prisoners, to prevent being tracked, and to meet at a certain place appointed, and if they had occasion to collect together before they got to the place, it would be by youling like a wolf, cry of a turky, Owl, or some wild beast or bird, as agreed on before they separate, to prevent being discovered, the prisoners at night are secured by putnig the Unclear in a notch out in a sapling, and a stake drove by the side, to fasten the angle in, & ty'd at the Top, out of the prisoners reach, thus they march to their Sonns, where the prisoners are obliged to run the gantlet for some considerable distance, where every one may have a stroke, after which they adopt the prisoner, into the families, or other wise disspose of them.

8 mo. 1  5   The Indians returned & took their seats on some planks laid for that purpose, after some time the Wyondot Chief rose & addressed himself to the Commissioners, and said the Land purchased at the several treaties on the west side of the Ohio, was unjust, and reminded the Commissioners of their saying it was impossible to remove the people settled on the west side of the River, & said the Lands were his, and it was impossible to give them up, and that they might return back, & tell Washington so, they then rose and went a small space, but Capt Elliott follow’d them and pointed out some mistake, whereupon they returned and informed the Commissioners, they would take their Speech to the Council, and that they should hear from them in 5 or 6 days, soon after the Indians embarked on board their Boats with their English flag flying, we took this opportunity to forward friend’s Epistle, the letter we had wrote to the Indians, & detain’d by the Commissioners   with some addition, also a few lines to Col: McKee, desiring him to deliver the inclosed to the Indians, lest we should not have a personal conference with them. After breakfast I set out  alone on horseback to visit the Wyondots, who expected us on 7th day last, and found about 8 houses in the distance of half a mile, where they appear to live comfortable, have cornfields well cultivated, and comfortable Log & bark Cabbins with an excellent soil.

[catchword: poor]

poor blacks in captivity, two having made their escape from our present landlords son, were taken and likely to be brought back and I feared their sufferings would be grievous, and in the morning I found I should not live clear without remonstrating to the God on their behalf, that as they belonged to his Children, without whom no doubt he had great influence, I desired him to consider that they were in a state of captivity of their just right of freedom, and whether if his Children were taken captives by the Algerines or Indians, and were to make the same exertions for their Liberty, whether he would not justify, or even applaud them, which gained his attention, I likewise reminded him as a man professing religion, prayed and said grace before supper, I reminded him of part of our Lord's prayer forgive us our tresspasses as we forgive those that tresspass against us he replyd he had seriously thought of these matters, his wife was present, and attentive, and at length said, I thought before the gentleman said a word, that he was going to speak on this subject, having eased my mind in a good degree, we proceeded and called at his son's Cliczar, who owned one of the blacks, and had a further opportunity to ease my mind, the young man and his wife listened with attention, and I had reason to believe that our being at both places was right, we parted very friendly. The Col: gave us an account of his travails among the Indians, which I think worthy of note, He says he found them to the most kind hospitable people he was ever among, and one town of in particular, when he entered it, some of the men came, took his horse and fed him, and he himself was conducted to a house

which appear to be kept as a place of accommodation, here he was provided with necessaries, on one side of the house was a window, at which the women would hand in baskets of huckleberries and such fruit, and as soon as he received the present, they would step aside so that he could not see their faces, such was the modesty of those unacquainted with the white people, and he thinks they exceeded all other women, and that the Indians have no fear of any body stealing from them, their simple manners and kind treatment so affected him, as to make the tears trickle down his cheeks. We pushed for the block house about 30 miles but the rodes extremely rough, and night coming on so dark that our horses could not keep the road, and we were obliged to take our quarters, the leaves and bushes wet, with great difficulty to kindle a fire, spread our blankets on the wet ground and slept most of the night. We found ourselves in a forlorn situation, but reached the block house in about an hour, and got breakfast, started for Samuel Harrises at Loyal Seek, and arrived in the evening. I found my old friend and kinsman very much reduced, and not likely to recover, but in a discernable situation of mine, the family was glad to see us. We attended the meeting at munsey to satisfaction and went home with Samuel Wallace's family and dined. An appointed meeting was held at the same place, which was large and solid, and in the afternoon we had a meeting at Sam. Harrises, many came, and Harvest it was a profitable season, Samuel expressed his

Satisfaction it being the last he was ever likely to be at, he loves his friends, we returned to S Wallaces, After breakfast rode to William Ellis's and dined, after which rode a few miles where Jacob Lindley and W. E. turned off for Harrisburgh, J.M. J C and myself accompanied by Joseph Carpenter rode to John Ever's about 20 miles. Morning we had a meeting in a school house, which was crowded, and to a good degree of satisfaction, there being in this Neighboorhood 10 or 12 families of friends and professors with us, and no meeting nearer than 12 miles, and a creek to cross, which with the unclear of most of their horses by a distemper, made it difficult for them to attend, in the afternoon we rode to Job Henres's about 14 miles, where Hodged, and being unwell this fatigue and exposure was obliged to travel slow. Set out for Cathwifes through a rough mountainous country, and arrived in the evening, a handsome little village, on the Susquehama, lodged at John Lloyd's jur. We visted most of the families of friends here, and then rode to maiden creek, on our way we met our kind friend Mordicai Lea, who took us to his house, and I continuing unwell was obliged soon to lie down, and had a severe fit of ague and fever. A little better, attended Maiden Creek meeting, which was a strengthening season to weary travellers, returned and dined with Mordicai Lea, and in the afternoon rode to reading and lodged at Sam. Jackson's, and were kindly entertained I continuing feeble. The Speech of the Commissioners of the undo hates, delivered to the Dyutation of the confederate Indian nation assembled at the rapid of the Miami Rivers. Brother, you, yesterday addresses, mentioning a former deputation, who met us at Niagara, at that meeting you said we did not come to a right understanding, that your deputies did not fully explain your meaning to us, nor we ours to them, that you desired we my rightly understand each other, and therefore thought it best, that what you had today should be put unto writing then handing us the paper, you said "here is the meaning of our hearts. Brothers, the deliwties we vent to you did not fully explain our meaning, we have therefore vent others to meet you once more, that you may fully understand the great lucation we have to ask of you, and to which we expect an explicit answer in writing. Brothers, you are vent there by the United States, in order to make peace with us, the confederate Indians. Brothers, you know very well, that the boundary line which was run between the white people and us, at the Treaty of Fort Hamuix, was the river Ohio. Brothers, if you seriously design to make a firm and lasting peace, you will immediately remove all your people from our side of that river. Brothers, we therefore ask you, are you fully authorized by the United States, to continue and firmly fix on the Ohio River as the boundary line, between your people and ours.

Brothers, the deputies here present, we have now repeated the words contained in that paper, which you delivered to us, we presume the interpretation agrees with your ideas of the contents of the paper, it is expressed to be signed by the Wyondols, Delaniares, Shanenees, Miamies, Mingoes, Potowatimies, Ottawas, Connays, Chippewas and Mundes, in behalf of themselves and the whole confederacy, and agreed to in a full council. Brothers,  we are a little surprised at the suggestion that in the conference at Niagara, we did not come to a right understanding and that your deputies did not fully explain your meaning, those deputies appeared to be men of good sense, and when we saw them, they were perfectly sober, in short, we never saw men in public Council more attentive, or behave with more propriety, we could not therefore suppose they could mistake your meaning or ours, certainly, we were sufficiently explicit, for in plain Words, we declared, that in order to establish a just and permanent peace, some concessions would be necessary on your part as well as ours, these words, brothers, are a part of our speech to your deputies, and that speech they assured us they fully understand what those concessions should be on both sides, and where the boundary line should be fixed, were proper subjects of discussion at the Treaty, when we should speak face to face, this we are certain would be the best way to remove all difficulties, but your nations have adopted another mode, which by keeping us at a distance, prevents our knowing each other, and keeps alive those jealouses which are the greatest obstacles to a peace, we are therefore desirous of meeting your nations in full Council without more delay, we have already waited in this province sixty days beyond the time appointed for opening the treaty.

Brothers, We have now explained our opinion of the proper mode of settling the difference between you and the United States, but as your nations have desired answers to certain questions, previous to our meeting, and we are disposed to act with frankness and sincerity, we will you an explicit answer to the great question you have now proposed to us, but before we do this, we think it necessary to look back to some former transactions, and we desire your patience to hear us. Brothers, we do know very well, that at the Treaty of Fort Hamwise twenty five years ago, the river Ohio was agreed on as a boundary between you and the white people of the British Colonies, and we all know, that about seven years after that boundary was fixed, a quarrel broke out between your father the king of Great Britain and the people of those colonies , which are now the United States, this quarrel was ended by the Treaty of Peace made with the King, about ten years ago, by which the Great Lakes, and the waters which united them, were by him declared to be the boundaries of the United States. Brothers, peace having thus been made between the King of Great Britain and the United States, it remained to make peace between them and the Indian Nations, who had taken part with the King, for this purpose commissioners were appointed, who sent messages to to all those Indian Nations, inviting them to come and make peace, the first treaty was held about nine years ago, with the six nations at Fort Hamwise, which has stood firm and unviolated to this day, the next treaty was made about ninety days after at Fort M. Intosh, with the half king of the Wyondols, Captain Pipe and other Chiefs in behalf of the Wyndols, Delaware, Ottawa, and Chippewa Nations,

1793      Afterwards treaties were made with divers Indian Nations south of the River Ohio, and the next treaty was made with Kakai pilatltey here present, and other shown Chiefs in behalf of the shannee Nation, at the mouth of the great miamie, which runs into Ohio. Brothers, The Commissioners who concluded these treaties on behalf of the United States, sent the papers containing them to the great Council of the States, who supposing them satisfactory to the Nations treated with, proceeded to dispose of large tracts of Lands there by reded, and a great number of people removed from other parts of the United States, and settled upon them, also many families of your antient fathers the French came over the great Water, & settled on a part of the same Lands. Brothers, After sometime it appear'd that a number of people in your Nations, were dissatisfied with the treaties of fort M: Intosh & Miamies, therefore the great Council of the United States, appointed governor St: Clair their Commissioner with full power for the purpose of removing all causes of controversy, regulating trade, and settling boundaries between the Indian Nations in the northern Department of the United States, he accordingly sent Messages inviting all the Nations concerned to meet him at a Council fire, which he kindled at the falls of Muskingum, while he was waiting for them, some mischief happened at that place, and the fire was put out, so he kindled a council fire at fort Harmer, where near six hundred Indians of different Nations attended, the six Nations there renew'd and confirm'd the treaty of fort Stanwix, and the Wyondots & Delawares Unclear

renewed and confirmed the treaty of the fort M. Intosh, some Ottawas, Chippeways, Patowatimies, and Sacs were also parties to this treaty of Fort Harmer. Brothers, we have also the speeches of many chiefs who attended them, and voluntarily declared their satisfaction with the terms of these treaties. Brothers, after making all these treaties, and after hearing the chiefs freely express their satisfaction with them, the United States expected to enjoy peace and tranquility to hold the lands ceded by them, accordingly large tracts have been sold and settled as before mentioned, and now Brothers, we answer explicitly, that for the reasons here stated to you, it is impossible to make the River Ohio the boundary between your people, and the people of the United States. Brothers, you are men of understanding, and if you consider the customs of white people, the great expense which attend their settling in a new Country, the nature of their improvements in building houses and barns, and farming and fencing their lands, how valuable the lands are thus rendered, and hence how dear they are to them, you will see that it is now impractical to remove our people from the northern side of the Ohio, your Brothers the English knew the nature of the white people, and they knew that under the circumstances which we have mentioned, the United States cannot make the Ohio the boundary between you and me. Brothers, you seem to consider all the lands in dispute on your side of the Ohio, as claimed by the United States, but suffer us to remind you, that a large tract was sold by the Wyondols and Delaware nations to the state of Pennsylvania, this tract lies east of a line drawn from the mouth of Beevers creek at the Ohio, due north

north to Lake Erie, this line is the western boundary of Pennsylvania as claimed under the charter given by the King of England to your antient friend William Penn, of this sale made by the Wyondol and Delaware Nations to the state of Pennsylvania, we have never heard any complaint. Brothers, we are on the occasion obliged to make are speech, we again desire you to hear us patiently, the business is of the highest importance, and a great many words are necessary fully to explain it, for we desire you may perfectly understand us, and there is no danger of your forgetting what we say, because we will give you our speech in writing. Brothers, the concessions which we think necessary on your part are, that you yield up, and finally relinquish to the United States some of the lands on your side of the Ohio, the United States wish to have confirmed all the lands ceded to them by the treaty of Fort Harmers and also a small tract of land at the rapids of the Ohio claimed by General Clarke, for the use of himself and his warriors, and in consideration there of, the United States would give such a large sum in money or goods, as we never given at any one time for the quantity of Indian Lands, since the white people first set their feet on the Island, and because those lands did every year farm you with skins and furs, with which you bought loathes, and other necessaries, the United States will now unclear you the like constant supplies, and therefore besides the great sum to be delivered at once, they will every year deliver you a large quantity of such goods, as are

1793

           suited to the wants of your selves, your women & children. Brothers, I fall in the lands before mentioned, cannot be yielded up to the United States, then we shall desire to treat and agree with you on a new boundary line, and for the Quantity of Land you relinquish to us within that new boundary, we shall stipulate a generous Compensation, not only for a large sum to be paid at once; but for a yearly rent for the benefit of yourselves and your Children for ever. Brothers, Here you see one concession which we are willing to make on the part of the United States, now listen to another claim which probably has more disturbed your minds than any other whatever. Brothers, The commissioners of the United States, have formerly set up a claim to your whole country southward of the great Lakes, as the property of the united states, grounding this claim on the treaty of peace with your father the King of great Brittain, who declared, as we have before mentioned, the middle of those Lakes, and of the waters which United them, to be the Boundaries of the United States. Brothers, We are determin'd that our whole conduct shall be marked with openngs, and sincerity, we therefore frankly tell you, that we think those Commissioners put an erroneous construction on that part of our treaty with the King, as he had not purchased the Country of you, of course he could not give it away, he only relinquished to the United States, his claim to it, that claim as founded on a right acquired by treaty with other white nations, to exclude them from purchasing or settling in any part of your Country, and it is this right which the King granted to the United States, before that grant, the King alone had a right to purchase of the Indian nations, any of the Lands between the great Lakes, the Ohio & the Mississippi, excepting the part within the Charter boundary of Pennsylvania, and the King by the treaty

treaty of peace, having granted this right to the United States, they alone have now the right of purchasing, so that now neither the King, nor any of his people have a right to interfere with the United States, in respect to any part of those lands, all your Brothers the English know this to be true, and it agrees with the declaration of Lord Dorchester, to your deputies of at Luebee two years ago. Brothers, we now concede this great point, we by this express authority of the President of the United States, acknowledge the property or right of soil of the great country above described, to be in the Indian Nations, so long as they desire to occupy the same, we only claim particular tracts in till, as before mentioned, and the general right granted by the King as above stated, and which is well known to the English and America and called the right of preemption, or the right of purchasing of the Indian Nations to sell their lands, to the exclusion of all other white people whatever. Brothers, we have now opened our hearts to you, we are happy in having the opportunity of doing it, though we should have been more happy to have done it in the full council of your nations, we expect soon to have this satisfaction, and that your next deputation will take us by the hand, and lead us to treaty, when we meet and converse with each other freely, we may more easily remove any difficulties, which may come in the way of peace. At Capt. Elliotts at the mouth of Detroit river 31. July 1793. Commissioners: Benjamin Lincoln, Beverly Randolf, Timothy Pichering

Third Journey. Left home about 8 o'clock in the morning under a sense of duty in company with my beloved friends David Bacon, William Savory and James Emlen to attend a treaty with the six nations of Indians intend to be held in the Seneca Country at a place Canada
qua about 300 miles from Philadelphia, we refreshed ourselves at Casper Haines in Germantown from there rode to Joseph Potts's and diner. From hence to Perquioma and bathed, washed ourselves and horses from hence to Potts Town and lodge at our kind friend Jhs. Rutter's it was an exercising day's journey thro' the heat, but a confirming sense of the rectitude of our present under taking was comfortable. A rainy morning, set out about 10 o'clock and rode to reading about 18 miles and lodged at Samuel Jacksons. Rose early and rode to Maiden Creek about 10 miles to breakfast, from hence about 7 miles to Carter's Town and bated, from hence to Stevens's about 8 miles and dined, from hence to the Widow Hallowell's about 9 miles. Rose early and rode over the Locus Mountain to Devall-Trash about 6 miles to breakfast, the morning being pleasant we travelled cheerfully, tho' the road exceeding mountainous and stony, and rain coming on we continued forward about 14 miles to Laden Burgars and dined, after which we stoped and led at a waist house, and got to Cattewise in the evening about 13 miles and Lode John Merrisse's. Called to new R. Nisbitt's family and divers friends the borded the Susquehanna and rode to Hugh Watson's and refreshed ourselves, and of whom I brought agreed

young Marcs left my horse in his care, thinking the journey would be too hard for him, from hence we rode to M. O'Keleys and dined from hence to W.M. Eellis's being about 155 miles from home here David Bacon and T lodged W. Savory and J. Emlin rode to Samuel Wallace's. I wrote home then we rode to our companions and from hence about 6 miles to the widow Harvis's at Loyal Dock and lodged. Rode to Riles and dined about 14 miles, from hence 20 miles to the Block House in the evening, we saw two Bares and crossed the trout run 32 times, the road extreme hony and mountainous, the Lerrel hill difficult to ascend, I believe it is 1/2 miles high, the Block House is a place of poor entertainment about 18 miles from any inhabitants but the landlord was very entertaining so that we passed the time toperably. Paid our reckoning 32 and set off early rode to Tioga about 10 miles and excessive bad roads, that it was difficult to travel 3 miles an hour, from hence at out 12 miles to Peter Roberts' where David and I lodged, Williams and James went about 5 miles further and lodged at one Daniels. Rode to our companions and breakfasted, from hence to Major Linley's, called to see Col. Lindley's Widow to good satisfaction, where we lodged on our return from Canada last year, from hence to the painted post where we met Guy Machwell Csqv. who set out with us to the treaty of whose company we were glad, we reached bath in the evening 39 miles and lodged at WM. Danns, pretty good entertainment, it was a wild forest per he an 18 months ago now a cleve village

Rode to the head of Canadoque Lake about 30 miles and lodged at Cap. Medcaff's. Rode thro' a rich country down the Lake and bated at Gilberts, from New England, from hence to the place of our destination about 22 miles and 320 from home, here we met with Timothy Pickering Commissioner to treat with the Indians, it was cause of humble rejoicing to be at the end of our journey in good health, and having travelled together in true harmony. Our kind friends Israel Chapin, agent for Indian affairs, hearing of our coming provided for us lodging at James Dennis', the best in the town. We walked from one end of the town to the other about half a mile in one hreet, with seething houses some of them large and elegant, a beautiful situation extending from one end of the lake north on rising ground to a considerable eminence, affording our extensive prospect, we called to see you gen! Chapin who treated us kindly, here we met with three professing with us, and were informed of several men we rejoiced and felt together like brethren in the afternoon, HW met with T. Pickering and 36 Anida Indians, they presented 2 Hring of Wampan on one was the ceremony of unstoping the throat that the voice might be strong, opening the eyes and clearing away the mist or dust that they might see clear and on the other hring a pathetic speech on condoleing the Pass of the dead, where they

they wished to be kept up, Col. Pickering made them a suitable answer, and we returned to our lodgeing glad of this interview with those Indians, we also had visits from several persons of note in the World. Heavy weather and some rain, we went, but little out but provided a place to hold a meeting in. We held a meeting in a school house, which was filled with respectable people who behaved agreeably well and the meeting closed in solemn supplication, under a sense of the Lords presence crowning our assembly, I could not wish myself elsewhere, tho' I affectionately remembered friends at home, in the afternoon we met again about the 11th hour, and light springing up it was a season of favour, may the Lord be praised. We walked thro' the Indian encampment, about 50 cabbins, they appear'd in their native simplicity, and glad to see us, after taking them generally by the hand we returned and met a man and woman who had been captives among the Shawnees, and had escaped, and were going to their relations at Greenbry or in Virginia, they gave an affecting account of their sufferings which raised in me rened desires that the day may hasten when the knowledge of the Lord shall cover the Earth as the Waters do the Seas. We rod to Abraham Lapham's about 5 miles, a fine rich country with plenty of sugar maple, Abraham was disowned by friends for moving into this country, his wife and children are members, we had a setting in the family and several neighbors came in several of whom also proper with us. We rode about 5 miles to Nathan Cumstocks, he having been disowned by friends, his wife appears to be a valuable friend, there are in this settlement about 30 persons.

1794
110mo: 14                 Women & Children, members of Society who appear to conduct orderly, and from my feelings I shall not think it Strange if they increase, and a Meeting in future allow'd them, 21 years ago I visited Redstone Settlement and the prospect there then, was not much more favourable This Country is not so well watered as some others but the people appear comfortable and their Cattle & Unclear as well as in other places__In the evening we returned to Canadoqila. Our friend Hannah Barnet from Hudson on the North river visited this settlement about two years ago, and I believe from accounts had acceptable Service, No Indians are yet come but the the Onidas, some of whom drink to excels, and of course are noisy it is a great mistake in Government to supply them with strong drink, when they are guilty of any outrage, they say the Liquor has done it, and with too much truth, they blame the white People for their corruptions, and Indian told me, the Indians did not know how to sware before the white people came along them, and now says he, I could sware this room full! O Christendom, mourn for the abomit nations in thy land, From whenee come wars and fighting, come they not from hence even from your lusts.  In the afternoon we went to see Wm Ingle's family, about 2 miles, he is a situated on a beautiful eminence where he has a prospect of the Town and of the Lake, has made great improvement, in about 3 years, his wife & Children have a right among friends, I felt for the situation of these people, especially for the rising generation, and hope they may so attend to the dictates of divine instruction, as to become as morning startsin a wilderness country

We went to the outlet of the lake and cast a hook, but took but little in afternoon we called to see General Chapin and from hence to drink tea with Thomas Morris, after which returned to our lodging. A cold snowy morning, the decent behaviour and kind treatment from our landlord and wife, made us content, and it is cause of gratitude to see the kindness and respect shown to us from all sorts of people. We held a meeting to a good degree of satisfaction with a decent company of people. We went about 2 miles to see one uhtico from Bucks County, he had a birth right among friends, but married another way, and appear'd to have but little sense of friends principles. We rode about 19 miles to judge Petters and lodged, he is a respectable man and with his son Arnold has made considerable improvement, he had 12 hacks of wheat in his barn yard, they have a gmily saw mill with many thousands acres of land. Arnold went with us about 3 miles to Temimar Welhinson's, she lives in no small hale with her attendants about her, when we went in we were met by Rachel Malon a young woman from Philadelphia, the friend as she is called was in another room, and after, some enquiry whether she was at home, and W Sexpress' a desire to see her, Rachel went into the next room, and after some time she came out and spoke to us, and soon after taking her seat began (as tem inform'd is her usual way) to tell of here experience and desire for the good of souls, together with the persecution and abuse she had met with, that friends of the meeting she came from in New England where she said she had the word of the Lord to deliver, had undertaken to silence her in

public meeting, and that she had left them after shaking off the dust from her feet against them, as I had never been in her company before, her behaviour and dress appears the more extraordinary, both tending to deny her being female, and was so artfully conducted together with her masculine countenance, that I should have supposed her to have been a man, not only by her dress and deportment, but her hand was far from the delicacy of a woman as well as her spelling, her followers are much declined, Rachel Malon who appears to be a well disposed young woman still remains with her, and supplies the place of Sarah Richards who is removed by death, and its said was kept a considerable time to raise her again, I sat under a considerable exercise and came away burthened, seeing now way for relief We went from hence to Judge Cotters and dined, and in the afternoon about 9 miles to Gilberts and fed our horses, and got to our lodging in the evening about 4 miles further. Morning, James Emlin and I set out to meet the Seneca Indians who were said to be on their waybetween Genesee and Canadoqua, we passed through a fine fertile country and unclear large farms in high cultivation, far beyond our expectation, and one them knew me, and called out sutty kutty, an Indian name given by the farmer's brother when in Philadelphia, we rode on and got to Berrys on the river side in the evening about 24 miles, it being the outwardboundary of the United States, purchased of the Indians, where was the main body encamped in bush cabbins, and were preparing for a dance, we put up our horses and soon after came to Jonathan the

the young King's Brother, who expressed his gladness to see us, pointing his finger upwards, and thanked the great spirit for our safe arrival, his example was followed by the interpreter, about 6 feet 5 inches high, and divers others who knew me. Rose early and received visits from several Indians who took us by the hand in a friendly manner, while I was writing Capt. John Garrison came about 2 miles, he said he was one of the first settlers in this country, and he was of opinion that our sort of people would do more towards civilizing the Indians than all the presents the United States could give Thomas Green a white Indian says the quakers made the first chain of friendship, and that the Indians think them the best people in the world, he has long been initiated among them, and attended treaties many years back. James and I walked to their cabins and smoked a pipe with them. In the afternoon we eroped the river into the Indian territory to a place called the Cautie, a beautiful extensive flat, ready prepared for the plow, this place was the extent of Sullanian's march, when he made such destruction of the natives, it was said his army destroy'd 32 towns, and since we left home we have been informed by a man from New England, that he has been reduced to a hale of insanity, well might he say with a great hero King Alfred, that the giving one loaf of bread to a poor person, had afforded him more satisfaction in the conclusion, than all the victories he had ever gained in war.

This evening a runner came in and informed that corn planter with about 100 Indians was coming, this runner it is said ran about 50 miles in less than 24 hours. Morning, we walked to the Indian Camp and informed the farmer's brother that we intended to return, and that it would be agreeable to know when they intended to move for Canadoque - after a consultation with the chiefs he informed us thro' Craska Jones Interpreter, that they had received intelligence by a runner that the brethren of the Seneca Nation about 100 had arrived last evening at big tree, a nearer rout to the place appointed, and did not expect to set out until tomorrow, with which information they were satisfied, and had concluded to move at the same time, apprehending it would not tend to forward the business to move sooner, as part of several tribes were yet behind and After he ended his speech, I informed them that we had come a great way through no small difficulty at their request, and with a desire for their welfare, but did not wish to hurry on the business faster than circumstances would admit, tho' we wished to return to our families and friends, and as the business was weighty and of great importance, I desired they might turn their mind to the great spirit, to week a qualification for the happy accomplishment of so desirable a work, which they approbated by yoho, yoho, soon after we took leave of them, and returned to our friends where we arrived in the weming to our mutual joy. We held a meeting at our lodgeings, to which a considerable number came, both of white people and Indians, the opportunity was comfortable and satisfactory - in the afternoon we went to the Indians

Indian incampment and sat down among them on some logs, and many of both colours being gathered, after a shortshaw of Dipenee the Indians opened their palm book, and sang a hymn, the men began and the women follow'd with a soft melodious voice, which exceeded anything of the kind that we had heard, a solemmity attending, I believe we united in heart in that melody, the apostle spoke of, altho' we kept silent until they were done after which some observations were offered, under a solemnity which crowned the assembly, and we returned to our lodging with thankfulness, believing that were in our proper places - I think it worthy of note, Capt. Bhapin informed me that he attend a conference with the six nations at Buffalo Creek, and a man there who had been very profane was near expiring in great agony, which touched his feelings with sympathy of expression, the farmer's brother reply'd he did not pity him no more than a dog, for he had heard the object say the great spirit had nothing to do with him, the blood that run in his veins was the support of his body, as though he was not a dependent being, but now pay the Indian the great spirit has fortaken gim, and given him over to the bad spirit to torment him, and he seem expired

Col. Pickering returned the Indians an answer to the speech delivered to him by the Onidas on 7th day past, complaining of grievances occasioned by their peasing 61440 Aerus of land to Peter Smith for 27 years at 210 dollars per year, and likewise 6 miles square to one Yanop a dark man for 99 years at 200 dollars per, which had occasioned a wide breach between the Sachems and Warriors, which they were more desirous to have healed than their land restored, and desired his assistance there in - the commission in his reply which was wrote down wished them to have patience to hear him and I thought his speech well adapted to the occasion. After he had done speaking the Indians desired him and us to withdraw, that they might confer together, after a little time we had notice to return and Capt. John a brave looking sensible man, told the Col. his speech was so length, he could not recount all it contained, and acknowledged the Indians had acted unwisely in disposing of their land; but the white people knew their weakness, would get them together and place a bottle of spirits before them, and when they were merry, then the white people would propose to purchase land, and when they had given them promise, they thought it dishonorable to go back, altho' disqualified on reflective next morning; but it could not be thought strange if individuals cheated them, when government set the example, he repeated what the commessd had said respecting fines and imprisonment of such as acted contrary to law, in purchasing Indian lands, which he said they did not wish to have carried into execution on their account, but

but wished to have his assistance in getting justice done them, he said they had laws and regulations among themselves, and as the Sachems were invested with power agreeable to their laws and customs, when any business was transacted accordingly, it ought to be binding, the commissioner promised to assist them both respecting their land and to reconcile the difference - the conference lasted about 3 hours, the Col. acknowledged they had been greatly wronged. The farmer's brother and company came in, they made a very formidable appearance, painted with their rifles on their shoulders, and extended from front to rear about 200 yards, the farmer's brother at their head as general, and when they advanced to the place appointed, where stood the Com. and Agent, they formed into a line of order and discharged their rifles with vollies, The Onidas who had been waiting drew up on the other side of the way and returned the like compliment, the two officers under appointment by government seated themselves in chairs on the green, the Indians encircled them, and the farmers brother rose with several things of Wampom in his hand addressing himself to the Commisioner, and thanked the great spirit that they were now met, and believed it was in the order of the great spirit, that things were concluded, the comic. and agent made some reply and requested to know their number, that proper provision might be made and they produced Lc72 Slicks. William Savory and I set out to meet the corn planter and company, but they not being so near as sepeeled we returned after having a view of some fine fertile land

James Emlin and I went to meet the corn planter and his company, the corn planter lead the way well mounted on horse back, and well dress'd, he took us by the hand with marks of true friendship, and they all soon encamped, it was pleasing to see their activity in falling and barking trees so that in about 2 or 3 hours they ere comfortably fixed on a spot well chosen by Arivilet and spread about 1/4 miles. In the afternoon they marched into town, agreeable to their custom, nearly as the farmer's brother did, Col. Pickering bid them welcome in a congratulating speech, and retired, little billy observed to the Com. that after he had been waiting for their arrival, there was no place provided to hold consel in, not even a bus to kick off the rain, which somewhat confused the Com., but excused the matter as well as he could, the stick being delivered according to the different tribes they amounted to 389. This morning several Indians of different tribes came to see us, and in the afternoon we went to see WM. Ingles family, they profess with us. This morning many Indians came to see us, corn planter, red jacket and others mentioned the case of Hopewell lands, and pointed to two antient men, whom they said were original owners, and expressed their thankfulness that the Quakers were disposed to do them justice, and to see it done by others, and delivered three strings of Wampon, then with drew to hold counsel among themselves about public affairs, in the afternoon the counsel met in the new court house the first time, the Indians agreeable to their custom went through the ceremony for the dead of different nations and tribes, and several length speeches made on belts and

anything of Wampom in a solid and serious manners to remove the grief from each others hearts, and to wipe one anothers eyes, and give a cheerful countinanced, to be prepared for the weighty business likely to come before them, during all this, they observed the utmost regularity and good order, Col. Pickering was so far made to understand their conduct, that he made a suitable approbating speech on the occasion, but contradictory there to he had them served with whisky, the bad  effects of which is daily seen, and if continued in all attempts to civilize the Indians will be abortive. We rode about 8 miles to Jonathan Smith's and held a meeting to good satisfaction, there are about 27 persons in this part of the country who have a right among friends, after meeting we returned back as far as Abraham Laphams and lodged. Returned, and in the afternoon met the Indians in council, Col. Pickering went thro' the formality of taking the hatchet out of the Indians head who had been helped by a white man at Vanango, about 18 months ago, and burying and putting the hatchet underground, and planting a pine tree on it, so that it should be remember'd no more, on which occasion he delivered many hringsof Wampom to the amount of nearly 100 dollars, the farmer's brother then rose and spoke to the different tribes, which I did not understand, but his manner and address I thought was equal if not superior to any things had heard by the learned, on the congress floor. We rode to the corn planter's encampment and our way saw a very extraording sight of about 12 or 15 Indians almost naked, highly decorated with various colours; on our return they began to dance with great activity, moving forward with a multitude after them and sometimes they shouled with one accord, this we were left was designed for a brag dance, but we did not stay to hear their

their exploits, in the afternoon we attended the council, the farmer's brother, Redjacket, Cornplanter, Tiwhearrier, Bigbully, and Little Billy set together with 6 or 7 Hring of Wampom in various colours on a table before them, and appear'd very studious over them, at length fishcarrier rose with several in his hand, and began to speak like one a reading with suitable pauses, the purport of which was observations on Col. Pickering's speech yesterday, relative to the Indian killed at pine creek (vanango) for which the Col. thanks them with promises of friendship, and informed them that some of their old friends the Quakers were present, and had a speech in writing from their council at home approved by the great chief of the United States, and they soon agreed that the present time was a suitable one to hear it read, and our friend W.S. read it distinctly with proper stops, so that Jone the interpreter convey'd the sense to the Indians, and appear'd to do it justice, the Indians listened with great attention and stillness, as soon as the number of signers was mentioned (44) Jemimah Wilkinson with Rachel Malon and 4 men of her followers being present, Jemimah kneeled down and made a long prayer, and soon after began to speak to the Indians, I thought much in the pine of the preists, and if her communications had been as weighly as lengthy I should not have been burdened. Jemimah Wilkinson and her company called to see us which gave an opportunity of relieving our minds more fully than when at her house, hold her I listen'd to what she said without reply when at her house, and reminded her that she ten acknowledged she had been a member of our society; but had left them and shaked the dust off her feet as a testimony against friends of the meeting she came from, she denied that she ever belong'd

belonged, but said she had gone to our meetings and other places, signifying to declare the word of the Lord, told her she could not be insensible that there had been strange reports of her, and as the Apostle said we should give an account of the hope within us, and as it was not not always best to take things by hearsay, I asked her if she had refused to be called by the name her parents had given her, I also informed her that it had been said she was displeased in being called a woman, which if false I should be glad should be glad to have it in my power to contradict the report; but to these things she waved an answer! by saying what signifies by what name we go by, and run into a multiplicity of words, as if she there by intended to prevent mere being said, told her I was concerned for those young people with her, who had been members of our society, and that I believed both she and they were under a delusion and after relieveing our minds in a good degree we parted tolerably friendly. The council met, and Indians produced a bundle of papers as records and ratifications of former treaties soon after our assembling word came of the decease of an antient Chief of the Onidas, which was expected would retard the Business, but after a short consultation Capt. John of the Onidas said the deceased had been sometime indisposed and his dissolution was not unexpected, it was the will of the great spirit to take him hence, and not withstanding it was their usual custom to defer business on such occasions, yet as the work of peace was also of the great spirit, he was easy they should proceed, three Indian women came in and requested the liberty of speaking which being granted they expatiated on the importance of their sex saying it was they that made the men and were acquainted from time to time with the transactions of treaties but their principal aim

aim was that the United States should grant the request made yesterday by the men, that they found themselves much distressed by being hemed in, but if the request was granted then they should feel much relieved, and expressed a desire that the great spirit might influence and direct in effecting the good work of peace for which the Com. thanked them and they withdrew. The commissioner then opened the business by recapitulating the speeches deliver'd yesterday by their Chief Warriors, wherein they had deserved that on the white people's rimeing into American the Indians finding them to be human beings, had granted them lands to live upon, that their numbers increased they had from time to time obtained were lands, till now they themselves were confined with in a very narrow compass, that the chain of friendships had long been preseved being, until the late war between the United States and the King of Great Britain, when it was suffered to fall off, and altho' it was in some sort attempted to be renew'd at Fort Hammex as follows. Article 3. a line shall be drawn beginning at the mouth of a creek about 4 miles east of Niagara, Ogonwayea of Johnson's Landing place upon the lake named by the Indian Oswego, from Henee southerly in a direction always 4 miles east of the carrying path between Lake Erie and Ontario to the mouth of Toheseroron, or Buffalo Creek on Lake Erie, then south to the north boundary of the Hate of Pennsylvania hence west to the end of the north boundary, hence south along the west boundary of the said state to the River Ohio, the said line from the mouth of the

1794 WD
10 mo: 935     the Ogonwagca to the Ohio shall be the Western boundary of the Lands of the six Nations, so that the 6 Nations shall and do yield to the United States all claims to the Country west of the said boundary, and then they shall be served in the peacefull Possession of the Lands they inhabit east and north of the same, reserveing only six miles square round the fort Oswego to the United States for the support of the same. The Indians apprehended themselves much aggrieved by the conduct of our Comm. at that Treaty as als at fort Harmon &. The Commissioners at fort Hanwex they said had alledged that the Country was now all theirs, and used such haughty & threatning Language that they were intimidated to such a degree as to sign what was contrary to their Judgements, since which the Chain had grown rusty, and that it was now time to brighten it, they therefore demanded that the United States should confirm to them a strip of Land about 15 or 20 miles wide from lake Erie extending in length from the seneca Country in the inmost part of New-York to the Western territory__ Col. Pichering acknowledged that there was too much Occasion for their Complaints against the said Commissioners; but hoped they would make some allowance when they consider'd that it was done at the close of a successful War when Victory had declared itself on our side &. 
246                  Snow'd all day we attended the burial of two Chiefs, of the Onida tribe, they were buried both in one grave the Indians performed some Ceremonies I suppose agreeable to their Custom, and when the dead was cevered up they fired the Rounds in the military

military way, but before they began Capt. John came to me and told me to take care of my horse they were going to fire, which I accepted as good will. Council met and Col. Pickering shenced great unceasing on account of Johnson a Brittish interpreter being present after a little time cornplanter rose, addressed himself to the 6 nations and all present, saying he was surprised that uneasiness should prevail that the English and Americans could not set in council together, and that it was requested by Col. Pickering at a treaty 4 years ago at Newton Point, that at future treaties some of the Brittish might be present, when we the Warriors and Sachens agreed that one of the Brittish should be present, and we are glad to see one here that has the care of us, he then deliver'd a message from Captain Brant directed to this council fire, which informs that at the time of his setting out for the western country, he had sent a Hring to inform them he was going, but was detained thro' sickness, he says after I had arrived at the place where I was going I met 3 nations, Shawnees, Delaware and Wyandots, and also the Miamies, after we set in council at the arrival of the 6 nations, you recollect that an attempt to meet the western Indians, the business did not go on, but the fault was not ours, they expressed a great joy again at their arrival, as they were great, we were deceived, and led astray, we got lost which they now inform their elder brothers the 6 nations, that their brothers the English were sitting by, and gave them no relief, don't be surprised we wish to have a treaty at St Dusky next spring, when there may be a general council fire for all

all nations - cornplanter spoke on other strings from Brant where in he sends his compliments to the Chiefs of the 6 Nations, letting them know it was thro' sickness he was presented coming to the council fire, and wishes whilst they are in council with the United States to remember what was agreed on with the lake Indians, when the line was marked out, and says if the line is complied with, I believe peace will take place - after you compleat them present business with the United States and General Washington, it is my request you will return to Buffalo Creek as soon as possible, and bring gen! Chapin and this message was brought by Johnson the Brittish interpreter who informs that Brant and Governor Jimeo arrived at Fort Erie from Detroit about 10 days ago. Col. Pickering told the Indians he was serious of returning home and supposed that they also had a desire to return to their Habitations,

unclear enough to receive brittish insolence, and more so to have a spy present, and so proceeded to state the misconduct of the Brittish both in Europe & America in high colours, especially respecting Indian Affairs, in so? much that the Indians laughing, said the fire was so hot that it occasiond the sparks to fly, they must take care of else they should be burned, which I thought was the closest reprimand I had ever heard, after which Johnson withdrew. Then Cornplanter rose and said the reason of the Council first? being cover'd up to day was caused by us, because here by our request, it is true I am very much disappointed & deceived & I will tel lyou the reason, we have been deceived by the white People at the unclear at fort Hanwex?, the unclear laid a paper before us pointing out the Terms of Peace, and said their Conduct was open to the great Spirit, & that the Chain of frienship was made bright, they informed us at that time of unclear actions of this unclear at fort Hanwex, and they told us a ly, it could not be in the presence of the great Spirit, I will speak but a few words in behalf of the Sachems, they request he may be sent off, but if he had his desire, Johnson should stay, that he might learn better, but it was the mind of the Sachems and Warriors, that he should have provisions for his accommodation on his return. And thus unclear that shew'd he unclear a Christian spirit.

1794
26   Unpleasant weather and a heavy season of exercise, no meeting held on account of the council being adjourning which we attended but to little purpose, the time being taken up with matters of no great consequence _ The Chiefs wrote by Johnson to Capt. Brant, giving an account of the Business,  and void those they were a poor deprived people, they were independent, and the White people were oppresive and  striving to see which should  be greatest; but their reliance was on the great Spirit_ We dined with the Commissioner in Company with the farmer's brother & others Chiefs.
272 No Council to day. This afternoon we receive a visit from Jaguarsy, a Head Chief of the Tuskaroras, a sedate sensitive man, and as there was a white man present who understood their Language, I took the opportunity to enquire of the Chief what was the Indians motives in requesting some friends to attend the present Treaty, informing that we were willing to do any service in our Power, consistent with our Principles, but we could have nothing to do with war , he said he would inform the other Tribes , and appears pleased to understand our principles more fully than hereto before, no that on the whole it was an acceptable visit, and I had an opportunity to communicate some matter which some weight on my mind, more fully than at any time hereafter.
283   Redjacket, his wife and 5 children dined with us which gave an opportunity of some satisfactory conversation where in our peaceable principles were pointed out to him and Thought made some impression on his mind, He said he had often hear their people talk of us in a council, and they intended speaking to us as soon as a convenient opportunity offered, Jones the interpreters.

Reflection
Having visited a sick Indian Woman who lay exposed in a cold Cabbin, and being myself this night comfortably accommodated in a warm Bed, I was lead to sympathise with the Natives in their exposed Situation, and faith arose that if this subject should claim the attention of our religious society to form a plan for their Civilization & improvement, similar to the Care of the Abolition Society for the Africans, that there are many charitable well disposed Persons who would cheerfully contribute toward the raising a fund for this purpose, whereby the present Generation may be greatly relieved, & their Children fitted to become useful members of Civil Society, the introduction of spirituous Liquors among them discouraged, & they more & more qualified to resist the Temptation, the baneful effects of which I have sorrowfully seen at this & former treaties, and my earnest desire is, that the unclear may be taken up under the direction of best Wisdom

Our Answer to the foregoing.
Brothers, We left our homes at your request, and have freely come to see you, and sat patiently with you during the transactions of the Treaty, we are glad to see the business brought to a close, we hope the Chain is brightned, and that the peace will be lasting, we have compared the Articles of the treaty given to the Indians with those retained by the United States, and find them to be true copies of each other, with respect to our signing, we hope you will excuse us, for altho' we believe no deceoption is intended by the Commissioner, yet there was a number of other people present, and we wish not to be held up to public view, as we informed you before, that we do not interfere with Government as we can take no part in War, neither do we apprehend ourselves competent Judges, as teh transactions at treaties held since the late War have not fully been made public, we hope you will abide by the agreement which you have signed & be at peace, and it is our earnest desire, that you might more & more be redeem'd from the Spirit of War, and cherish peace, this would conduce much to your happiness & prosperity, and greatly increase the number of your friends, as a Society we have had experience of the benefits arising from these peaceable principles for near the Space of 150 years, and we find we can do better without fighting than with, we wish that when you apprehend yourselves aggrieved, you would make your grievances known, and not seek to revenge them, we still continue to feel the same good will towards you our Brothers the Indians as formerly & are willing in every strait & difficulty to afford you any Assistance in our power, we fervently wish you may live in love one with another, and the God of peace will bless & preserve you
